# Problem Statement

---

## The Challenge

::: {.incremental}
- **Severe air pollution** in developing countries, especially during smog season
- **Indoor air quality** often overlooked despite people spending 80-90% of time indoors
- Traditional systems operate **manually** without intelligent decision-making
- Health impacts: headaches, breathing difficulties, allergies, asthma complications
:::

---

## Why It Matters

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="60%"}
### Indoor Pollutant Sources
- Cooking smoke and dust
- Cleaning agents and paints
- Furniture emissions
- Poor ventilation
- Outdoor smog infiltration
:::

::: {.column width="40%"}
### Current Gaps
- Manual operation required
- No real-time data processing
- Limited automation
- Lack of predictive capabilities
:::
:::

# Background / Literature Review

---

## Related Research {.smaller}

| Study | Key Finding |
|-------|-------------|
| **Kumar et al. (2021)** | Affordable sensors (MQ-135, PMS5003) can effectively monitor indoor air quality with cloud connectivity |
| **Zheng et al. (2020)** | ZigBee sensor networks provide low-cost, scalable monitoring for large buildings |
| **Liu & Wang (2019)** | Demand-controlled ventilation saves 35% energy while maintaining air quality |
| **Garcia et al. (2022)** | Adaptive purification using sensor feedback reduces energy by 40% |

---

## Existing Commercial Systems {.smaller}

::: {.incremental}
1. **Daikin Automated IAQ Management** - Integrates sensors with HVAC for dynamic ventilation
2. **Daikin ONE Home Air Monitor** - Monitors PM2.5, gases with HVAC ecosystem integration
3. **Field Controls WelSpace** - Real-time PM2.5, CO₂, VOCs, formaldehyde monitoring
4. **Honeywell TR50 IAQ Sensor** - Building automation-focused multi-parameter sensing
5. **IQAir AirVisual Pro** - Premium consumer-grade air quality monitoring
:::

---

## Research Gaps

::: {.incremental}
- **Sensor accuracy** deteriorates over time - better calibration needed
- Limited **real-time automated control** systems
- Need for more **user-friendly interfaces**
- Opportunity for **smart building integration**
- **Cost-effective solutions** for developing countries
:::

# Project Goals / Objectives

---

## Specific Project Aims

::: {.incremental}
1. Develop a **multi-sensor monitoring system** using ESP32
2. Implement **cloud-based machine learning** for air quality classification
3. Enable **automatic control** of ventilation devices
4. Create **mobile/web dashboard** for real-time monitoring
5. Ensure **scalability** for multiple rooms/buildings
6. Achieve **cost-effective** solution compared to commercial systems
:::

## Step 1: Data Collection Node {.smaller}

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
### Hardware Components
- **ESP32 microcontroller** (WiFi + Bluetooth)
- **Plantower PMS5003S** - PM1.0, PM2.5, PM10
- **SGP30** - TVOCs and eCO₂
- **ME3-CO** - Carbon Monoxide
- **MH-Z19C** - carbon dioxide
- **DHT22/BME280** - Temperature & Humidity
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
### Function
- Continuous real-time sensing
- Local data preprocessing
- Wireless transmission via WiFi
- MQTT protocol communication
:::
:::

---

## Step 2: Cloud Platform {.smaller}

### Cloud Responsibilities

::: {.incremental}
1. **Data Reception** - Receives sensor data via MQTT
2. **Data Storage** - Secure storage for historical analysis
3. **ML Processing** - Runs AirNet deep learning model
4. **Classification** - Categorizes air quality (Good/Moderate/Poor/Hazardous)
5. **Control Logic** - Determines ventilation actions
6. **Command Transmission** - Sends control signals to ESP32
7. **User Interface** - Powers mobile/web dashboard
8. **Notifications** - Alerts users of air quality changes
:::

---

## Communication Architecture

```{mermaid}
%%| fig-width: 10
sequenceDiagram
    participant S as ESP32 Sensors
    participant M as MQTT Broker
    participant C as Cloud Platform
    participant A as Mobile App
    
    S->>M: Publish sensor data
    M->>C: Forward data
    C->>C: ML processing
    C->>M: Publish control command
    M->>S: Forward command
    S->>S: Activate relay
    C->>A: Send data & alerts
```

---

## Machine Learning Model: AirNet {.smaller}

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="60%"}
### Model Overview
- **Deep learning-based** architecture
- Captures spatial and temporal patterns
- Originally for outdoor air quality forecasting
- Adapted for indoor environments

### Input Features
- PM2.5, PM10 concentrations
- Gas levels (CO₂, VOCs, NO₂, CO, SO₂)
- Temperature and humidity
- Temporal features (time of day, day of week)
:::

::: {.column width="40%"}
### Advantages
- High accuracy with nonlinear data
- Predictive capability
- Early warning system
- Adaptable to local conditions
- Better than traditional models
:::
:::

## Hardware Connection Details {.smaller}

| Component | Interface | Connection |
|-----------|-----------|------------|
| PMS5003S | UART | ESP32 RX/TX pins |
| SGP30 | I2C | SDA/SCL |
| ZE07-CO | UART | Via logic shifter |
| ZE03-NO₂ | UART | Via logic shifter |
| ZE03-SO₂ | UART | Via logic shifter |
| DHT22 | Digital | GPIO pin |
| Relay Module | Digital | GPIO pin (for fan control) |

# Discussion

---

## Expected Challenges

::: {.incremental}
1. **Sensor Calibration**
   - Low-cost sensors may drift over time
   - Solution: Regular calibration routines

2. **Network Reliability**
   - WiFi connectivity issues
   - Solution: Local buffering and retry logic

3. **Power Management**
   - Continuous operation requirements
   - Solution: Efficient coding and hardware selection
:::

---

## Expected Challenges (cont.)

::: {.incremental}
4. **ML Model Training**
   - Sufficient training data collection
   - Solution: Extended data collection period

5. **Real-time Processing**
   - Balancing accuracy and speed
   - Solution: Cloud-based processing

6. **User Adoption**
   - Making the system intuitive
   - Solution: User-centered design approach
:::
